items.message: The Flood Alert for the Upper Mole remains in force. Further rainfall is forecast this evening. Flooding is still possible until tomorrow morning 24 October 2025. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Property flooding is not expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling, or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message:
Tide locking where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea,  over the next three days may lead to flooding. 

Flooding is possible from today, Thursday 23 October, and over the weekend. 

We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  The Broads and river levels will remain high over the next couple of days due to tide locking from the current spring tides and surge from a low pressure system.

We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.  

Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 09:00am tomorrow, Friday 24 October 2025. or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Middle Mole remains in force. Further rainfall is expected this evening. Flooding is still possible until lunchtime on the 24 October 2025. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Property flooding is not expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling, or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 23 October 2025 . Half a month's rain (40mm) fell in the last 12 hrs. 
Minor flood impacts could be affecting Hammer Lane, Grove Hill, and Mill Lane, Hellingly. From 09:00 23/10/2025 flooding could affect fields, gardens, and Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Only a small amount of rain is forecast over the next 4 days. River levels have already peaked at Cowbeech, and should continue to fall. River levels are currently increasing in Hellingly, but should peak and start to fall by 14:00 23/10/2025. In Alfriston only minimal flood impacts are expected and river levels should fall by 22:00 23/10/2025. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Mill Ln Church Rd Hellingly, North St Alfriston). 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Uck
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels remain high and may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible overnight from the afternoon of 23 October 2025 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers along the Whitewater Dyke near Stanhope.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 23/10/2025, as a lot of rain (25mm) fell in the last 12 hours. Minor flood impacts could be affecting Bridge Cottage on the B2028 and roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. From 11:00 23/10/2025 minor flooding could affect the Anchor Inn and Barcombe Mills road. Slightly higher river levels than 20/10/2025. Only a small amount of rain is forecast over the next 5 days. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Ardingly by 15:00 23/10/2025 and by 22:00 on 23/10/2025 in Barcombe.  We are  closely monitoring the situation and operating structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to reduce flood risk. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood, including Barcombe Mills Road. This message will be updated by 24/12/2025 12:00.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, over the next three days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from today, Thursday 23rd October, and over the weekend. 
We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. The Broads and river levels will remain high over the next couple of days due to tide locking from the current spring tides and surge from a low pressure system. 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 10pm to midnight on 23/10/2025 
Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Lowestoft of 1.76 mAODN at 11pm, today,  23/10/2025, which is 0.81m above tide tables, Wind Force 8, Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 12:45am  to 2:45am on 24/10/2025 
Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.70mAODN at 1:45am, tomorrow,  24/10/2025, which is 0.72m above tide tables, Wind Force 7, Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.70mAODN at 1:45am, tomorrow,  24/10/2025, which is 0.72m above tide tables, Wind Force 7, Westerly. items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 03:15 AM to 05:15 AM on 24/10/2025. 
The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.67mAOD at 04:15 AM on 24/10/2025.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. Flooding of properties is not expected.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 25 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to continue to rise for the next 24 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.message:

Locations most affected will be the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded. Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 12:45am to 2:45am on Friday 24th October 2025. 
Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Clacton of 2.90mAODN at 1:45am, tomorrow,  Friday 24th October 2025, which is 0.58m above tide tables, Wind Force 7, Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 

Flooding is possible from 06:15 to 10:15 on 24.10.2025. 
 
Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  King's Lynn of 3.65mAODN at  08:15 on Friday  24 which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind force 7, westerly direction. Tides will remain high over the next couple of days. 
 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.  

Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by  12pm on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding is possible from 06:15 to 10:15 on 24.10.2025. 
 
Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  King's Lynn of 3.65mAODN at  08:15 on Friday  24 which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind force 7, westerly direction. Tides will remain high over the next couple of days. 

We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.  

Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves may lead to flooding this evening. 
 
Flooding is possible from 6.45 to 10.45 PM on 23/10/2025. 
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point: a forecast high water of 5.41 mAODN at 08.45 PM, with North West force 7 winds.
 
Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land, roads and paths, particularly around the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. 
 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update messages as the situation changes. 
 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded around the times of the high tides and take care. 
 
This message will be updated by 9:30 AM on 24 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the next high tide.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.  
The previous tide of concern has now passed,  the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.    
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.    
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Hollington Stream
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Minimal rainfall is expected over the next 5 days and river levels should continue to fall. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
